text: Leonard Bocour (March 18, 1910 - September 6, 1993) was an American artist. Bocour was born in New York City. Around 1933 he formed the New York City based company Bocour Artists Colors. He was the co-developer along with Sam Golden of Magna paint in the late 1940s. From 1952 until 1970 he and Sam Golden were partners in the Bocour Artists Colors Co. The company sold artist paints from the late 1930s until the 1990s. Many well-known artists from Mark Rothko, Jackson Pollock and Willem de Kooning to Helen Frankenthaler, Morris Louis, Knox Martin, Kenneth Noland, and hundreds of others bought paint from Leonard Bocour. The tubes of paint marked Bocour were watercolor or oil paint and the tubes labeled Bellini were oil paint. The acrylic paint was thick bodied and called Aquatec. He was a serious art collector, in addition to being a well-known paint manufacturer. He collected and owned works by many of his now famous customers. accessed online August 31, 2007 Bocour donated part of his collection to St. Mary's College of Maryland.Mulberry Tree Papers , 2002 ==See also== *Sam Golden *Golden Artist Colors *Magna paint ==References== ==External links== *Interview from the 1970s - Archives of American Art * Leonard Bocour papers and business records, 1933-1993 - Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution Category:1910 births Category:1993 deaths Category:Art Students League of New York alumni Category:American art collectors Category:Businesspeople from New York City Category:20th-century American businesspeople
title: Leonard Bocour
